ผู้จัดการความมั่งคั่งรายใหญ่ที่สุดของญี่ปุ่นลดตำแหน่ง crypto หลังจากขาดทุนในไตรมาสที่ 3

Japan’s biggest wealth manager reduces crypto positions after Q3 losses

5d ago//Tim Alper
general
AI

Summary

TH

โนมูระ (Nomura) ผู้จัดการสินทรัพย์รายใหญ่ที่สุดในญี่ปุ่น ที่มีสินทรัพย์ของลูกค้าประมาณ 153 ล้านล้านดอลลาร์ กำลังลดตำแหน่งในสกุลเงินดิจิทัลหลังจากเกิดขาดทุนในไตรมาสที่สาม บริษัทกำลังนำการจัดการความเสี่ยงที่เข้มงวดขึ้นมาใช้ในบริษัทในกำกับในยุโรปที่ชื่อ Laser Digital ซึ่งเป็นผู้ดูแลการค้าสกุลเงินดิจิทัล แม้จะมีการลดลงนี้ นายฮิโรยูกิ โมริอูจิ หัวหน้าฝ่ายการเงินของโนมูระ ได้เน้นย้ำว่า ความมุ่งมั่นของบริษัทต่อธุรกิจสินทรัพย์ดิจิทัลยังคงไม่เปลี่ยนแปลง และวางแผนที่จะขยายการดำเนินงานด้านคริปโตในระยะกลางถึงระยะยาว

EN

Nomura, Japan's largest wealth manager with approximately $153 trillion in client assets, is reducing its cryptocurrency positions following unspecified losses in the third quarter. The firm is implementing tighter risk management at its European crypto subsidiary, Laser Digital, which handles cryptocurrency trading operations. Despite this reduction, Nomura's chief financial officer Hiroyuki Moriuchi emphasized that the company's commitment to digital asset businesses remains unchanged and plans to expand these operations in the medium to long term.

Key Points

  • Nomura is reducing crypto positions after Q3 losses but remains committed to digital asset businesses long-term
  • The Japanese wealth manager is tightening risk management at its European crypto subsidiary Laser Digital
  • Laser Digital recently applied for a US national trust bank charter to offer crypto services throughout America

Article

Nomura to cut risk at European crypto subsidiary Laser Digital. Firm says it’s still committed to crypto. Laser Digital recently applied for US operating permit. Nomura, a Japanese brokerage with around $153 trillion in client assets, says it has “reduced its positions in cryptocurrencies” after its crypto arm suffered unspecified losses in the third quarter. The firm confirmed that it is reducing risk at its Europe-based crypto subsidiary Laser Digital, which handles its cryptocurrency trading operations. The comments came from Nomura’s chief financial officer Hiroyuki Moriuchi, according to Bloomberg Japan. Nomura’s “commitment to digital asset-related businesses remains unchanged,” Moriuchi said. He added that the firm hopes to expand its crypto-related business operations “in the medium to long term.” Japanese firms have shown a willingness to buck market trends and invest in Bitcoin and crypto-related business regardless of the choppy market conditions. But even the most bullish of the country’s crypto-keen companies appear not to be impervious to crypto prices’ recent dramatic falls . Reducing risk exposure Nomura is Japan’s biggest wealth manager, with around $153 trillion in client assets and control of around 15% of the domestic market. “We have tightened our management of positions, as well as risk exposure [to curb short-term volatility in profit],” Moriuchi said. The comments come shortly after Laser Digital lodged an application to operate as a federally chartered bank in the United States. Laser Digital has applied for a national trust bank charter, which would allow it to operate throughout the US, Financial Times reported last week. Nomura wants its subsidiary to offer US firms and residents a range of crypto custody and spot trading services. Nomura launched Laser Digital in Switzerland on September 21, 2022, stating the new firm would to focus on “digital assets, including cryptocurrency trading and venture capital.” In December 2022, officials said they expected the subsidiary to be turning a profit by 2024. Last year, Nomura and five other major Japanese wealth management players, indicated a willingness to launch crypto funds for domestic investors. Crypto market movers Bitcoin is down 5.3% over the past 24 hours, currently trading at $78,448. Ethereum is down 9.1% in the past 24 hours, trading at $2,402.
